lines.text: [first lines]

[answering the phone]
Obits, Jack Yeats speaking.
Paris, it's Beth!
Even paranoids have enemies. How do letterbombs work?
They blow you to bits when you open them. Jack, relax, none of the guys that would like to kill you know how to make a letterbomb; much less write a letter.

[after being chewed out by his boss]
Since when do obituary writers have deadlines.

[taking notes]
Catherine Sienna... Any relation to the saint?
The same that way you're related to the poet.
May I offer you a beverage?
Please. Double Jamesons, two cubes.

[relaying order]
Magdalena, Double Assumptions, two Holy Ghosts.
You have sorrowful eyes Mr. Yates.
I haven't been sleeping well.
I like that in a man.
Insomnia?
In the art is a flimsy mortal bastion. I like the evidence of ruins to your soul. It suggest intriguing possibilities to the physician.
The Garden of Eden was no great shakes.
I'll defer to your experience.
Do you know the parable of the Prodigal Son?
Some would say too well.
Consider this, killing the fatted cow could mean there's going to be an autopsy before there's going to be a feast.
How do I know you're not Paris?
Oh come now, Mr. Yates, if I were him, do you think I'd want to be me?
The dead are being very uncooperative.
Happiness *is* possible Beth. As long as all the parties make sure their inner-children are in bed before the streetlights go on, and spend the rest of the evening as adults.
Here's $150. Don't spend it all in one place.
I may only be going to one place...
You're an obituary writer and I'm a pathologist, what else but death would bring us together? Still an excuse for a party is fine with me.
Paris moved in mysterious ways.
We all respect the living, for the dead we have only the truth.
